intro: Alectorolophus elatus, commonly known as the golden cupflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. The golden cupflower thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks.
